Award.AwardTitle: Duke University Noyce Scholarship - Phase II

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Duke University Master of Arts in Teaching (MAT) Program, in collaboration with the Durham Public Schools and the STEM departments in the Trinity College of Arts and Sciences, establishes a Robert Noyce Scholarship Program Phase II Project to provide stipends to 30 Duke Noyce Scholars during the project period. This project has four goals: 1) Recruit and enroll diverse cohorts of highly-qualified STEM graduates and mid-career professionals; 2) Prepare teachers to improve student achievement in mathematics and the sciences; 3) Support new teachers during the first three years of their career as they teach in high-need school districts; and 4) Continue longitudinal evaluation and analysis of the project to determine those factors most effective in recruiting, preparing, and retaining highly-qualified teachers for high-need school districts.

This project extends and expands work completed in a Phase I project awarded in 2006. In particular it seeks to increase teacher retention and to attract more underrepresented minority STEM majors and professionals into STEM teaching. A comprehensive set of activities is implemented to reach these goals. This Noyce project seeks to build relationships with and recruit from prestigious historically black colleges and universities (HBCUs). The one-year MAT Program for Noyce Scholars includes a curriculum of pedagogical coursework, graduate coursework in the Mathematics and Science disciplines, and two-semester internships in high schools of Durham Public Schools. New teachers in their first three years in the profession are supported by an innovative, structured teacher mentoring program that includes the early-career Duke Noyce graduates, experienced Duke Noyce graduates, and faculty. Other support activities include bi-annual Noyce Learning Conference events and support of professional development through conference participation.

The broader impacts of this project include increasing the diversity of highly-qualified science and mathematics teachers and implementing a model to effectively recruit, prepare and retain STEM teachers. The systematic mentoring program for early-career teachers encourages higher teacher retention rates and provides a model that can be adapted at other programs. Through the evaluation activities, this project advances the understanding of strategies to develop and implement an effective MAT program for STEM majors and mid-career professionals and to support new teachers in high-need school districts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Award Title: Duke University Noyce Scholarship - Phase II

Federal Award ID: 1340044

Report Submission Period: 09/01/2019 to 08/31/2020

The Duke University Noyce Scholarship Program- Phase II (2013-2020) examined the effectiveness of Duke University?s Master of Arts in Teaching Program in recruiting, preparing, and retaining highly successful STEM graduates and career professionals in the teaching profession. Though Duke?s MAT Program has been successful at graduating highly qualified high school STEM teachers and initially placing them in high-need school districts, increasing teacher retention and attracting more teachers of color into the profession has remained elusive. Since teacher retention and recruitment is a persistent issue nationally, seeking remedies to this problem constitutes intellectual merit. In terms of broader impact, the project aimed to more fully understand the challenges beginning teachers face and identify the combination of supports most effective in recruiting and retaining STEM teachers.

During 2013-2020 period, Duke?s MAT program awarded 28 scholarships to graduate students with undergraduate degrees in math or science?16 in the sciences and 12 in mathematics. Approximately 25% were students of color and 64% were women. Data were collected from surveys, interviews, and focus groups, to examine program efforts to (1) recruit and enroll diverse cohorts of highly-qualified STEM graduates and professionals; (2) prepare teachers to improve student achievement in mathematics and the sciences; (3) support new teachers to teach in high-need school districts; and 4) continue longitudinal evaluation and analysis of Duke?s initial Phase I Noyce project (awarded in 2006).

Building on efforts from Duke?s Phase I Noyce project, the Noyce Phase II project increased enrollment of students of color by 7% even with total enrollment numbers remaining constant. Though these numbers are moving in the right direction, progress still needs to be made in recruiting STEM candidates of color. Enrollment of STEM professionals dropped by nearly 50% from Phase I to Phase II, and this decrease warrants a deeper investigation. One reason for the shift may be job growth in STEM fields over the last several years paired with a shortage in qualified professionals to fill the expanding need in STEM industries (National Science Board, 2012).

The Duke MAT Program?s rigorous coursework and intensive internships contribute to early-career success for Noyce graduates. During MAT teaching preparation, Noyce Scholars excelled in their graduate coursework, earning an average cumulative GPA of 3.83. At the end of their teaching internships, 100% of Noyce Scholars were evaluated as ?Effective? or ?Very Effective? teachers, as measured by an adapted form of the North Carolina Teacher Evaluation instrument. When asked about the impact Duke Noyce graduates had on student achievement after their first year of teaching, school administrators reported that Duke Noyce graduates ?Met? or ?Exceeded? expectations.

One of the main distinctions between the Phase I and Phase II projects is the incorporation of a mentorship component to support Noyce graduates during their first three years of teaching (Phase II intervention). This and other support mechanisms put in place during Phase II warrant continued investigation to determine if these interventions moderate the retention of Noyce graduates in high-need school systems.

In terms of the activities and support mechanisms put in place to achieve the Phase II Duke Noyce Program goals?the mentoring program, Duke Noyce Conference, Noyce Travel Grants, and the Duke Noyce Online Learning Center have successfully supported Duke Noyce Scholars and graduates. From 2013-2020,approximately 54 travel grants were awarded to Duke Noyce Scholars to support attendance at professional conferences.  Ninety-one percent of Duke Noyce Scholars indicated that attendance at the Duke Noyce Conference helped them become more effective educators.  

Mentors and mentees provided vital feedback regarding how the mentoring component of the program can be modified to better address their needs. As a result, the program remained fluid?structuring and re-structuring to customize support for participants. For example, face-to-face versus virtual seminars (i.e., Skype, Google Hangouts) were preferred by current participants?especially by those who are in close proximity to campus?thus the program decreased the number of virtual sessions and expanded face-to-face mentor/mentee seminars. Mentors also expressed the need for additional support around how to be an effective mentor and feedback from their mentee on the quality of the mentoring relationship. As a result, mentor training was intensified and the feedback loop closed.

Duke Noyce scholars consistently reported that the intensive internship (27 weeks and placement in two different high schools) is one of the best features of the program that prepared them for their first year of teaching. In addition, the incorporation of a ?needs assessment? that is completed by Noyce early career graduates revealed curricular resources and lesson planning, classroom management, and work/life balance are the greatest needs among Duke Noyce graduates. Of these, Noyce early career graduates reported they especially want the Noyce Program to help them with maintaining work/life balance.
